comment._content: Stu, I was trying to figure that one out also but the nearest were down outside the Savoy as I recall and that would be a long way from there.  I would have to say I agree with Patrick, the lower limbs on the good looking blonde make this an excellent shot for comparison!

comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content:
A fine street photo,
with The Mystery of the Bollard Perforations.

Wikipedia tells us:
Internally illuminated traffic bollards have been in existence throughout the United Kingdom since the 1930s,

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I would say they are air vents for the underground vault that is just to the left of the bollards.Vents for a below ground toilet or sanitary sewer vents would normally terminate much higher above ground. I could be completly wrong of course.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Yes I'd expect them to be a bit taller....Imagine the pong!
In cities with underground railways you can find similar bollard and vents, but Dublin did not have such a system.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: Could they have been used as a vent for gas mains? There's a manhole beside them?

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Those bollards get around. . . . vents for the basements that extended all the way out to the middle of the road.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Very interesting, when I eventually manage to come to Dublin I'll come and see them.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I think I'm in trouble now, somebody might "clipe" and inform the wife. to clipe means to tell or snitch on somebody, in Scots English www.firstfoot.com/dictionary/c.html I wonder if there's a similar expression in Irish English? A pair of cast iron bollards can lead a long, long way away!

comment._content: They are called suicide doors here in the U.S.. They have just started selling the new little Fiat over here recently, looks very like the 60's cars.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Those bollards have been on O'Connell street since the 19th century. I don't think they were illuminated. One of Pat Liddy's books suggested that they were ornate vents over basements. There was discussion about them on Archiseek a few years back. Arising after their (rather clumsy) relocation after some renovations. Have a look at the thread and the other images. Alongside other views of the leggy blond (from the NLI collection) the Archiseek bods posted images showing them "protecting" statues, as lamp bases, etc.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: NLI I resemble that!  I'm not mature just old and in my second childhood and looking forward to my second teenage years to appreciate photos like that all the more.

Hooray for archiseek!

comment.author: 46650209@N07

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: Personally if those bollards were still there I'd be sitting inside one... NLI you asked for all this...

comment.author: 32625786@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 

You are right, there was a Fiat factory in Dublin but I am not sure it was in Grand Canal Street.

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: from fleetcar.ie The company operated an assembly plant in Chapelizod before expanding and moving to Ballyfermot, where Fiat 127s and 128s were produced. Sales and administration offices also moved to the Kylemore Road and there was a company owned workshop and paint-shop in Grand Canal Street. It’s hard to know exactly how many people in total worked for Fiat over the years, but the figure of 600 is probably conservative (www.fleetcar.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=art...)

comment._content: classic street shot!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Chompsky on the excellent Broadsheet posted The Mystery of the Perforated Bollards yesterday, and there's some great argument over there as well. One gem is that the 1969 general election was held on 18 June, so this photo must have been taken around June/July 1969...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: The beautiful girl is, I hope, still living. She is in a thoughtful mood, finger to mouth and considering her options.  The cold concrete doesn't bother her, and she looks as if she has just sat on it. The newspaper is held, not as one reads an article, but as one scans for a job or, more likely, for an apartment. There were queues for apartments in Dublin at that time.  It is a most excellent picture.

comment.author: 77191617@N03
comment._content: An Taisce (The National Trust for Ireland) published a lovely book entitled "The Antique Pavement  - an illustrated guide to Dublin's street furniture" by Derry O'Connell in European Architectural Heritage Year 1975, which, amongst other things, features these "airvents/bollards" at the north end of O'Connell Street where this photo was taken. No other information is given, other than the statement that "many of them stood along the centre of the street in 1890" which doesn't seem to support the building basement theory? Could they have merely vented the pipes conveying rainwater runoff down the street towards the Liffey? The author - then a 4th year Architectural student at the college of technology, Bolton st., states that much of the detail he quotes was based on the memories of older Dubliners he interviewed, as well as from contemporary sources.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77191617@N03] So the mystery continues... Not giving up on this one yet - there must be someone out there that knows!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/micsworld/7783401390/ They're still there in 2012. This Mic V. seems to think they (or similar ones) were used to protect a statue of William Smith O'Brien statue at the entrance to D'Olier Street. Long ago they appear to have been the base to a gas lamp, and used as a safe drop-off point for taxi passengers. www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=49&t=2087&... Do I get another virtual prize?

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Ok, I don't need the prize that bad.
